Open the shutter of the mind and it will be flooded with light. -- Sri Nisargadatta Maharaj (1897 - 1981) (was an Indian spiritual teacher and philosopher of Advaita (Nondualism). According to Nisargadatta, the purpose of spirituality is to know who you are. -=- Photomaginarium Prints available. -=- the geek behind the curtain: all shots and layers in this photo art collage were taken and developed by myself. this started out as a sunrise shot from this morning (basically two-and-a-half hours ago) that i took from my car while parked at a median (on my way to work). taken with my hand-held point-and-shoot canon. as usual, all processing was done in the "open source" (free) program called GIMP. (the birds are a shot, on mulitple layers, from january.) the sunrise and treeline are copied onto 3 layers, two of them filtered with smaller and larger "cubism" blocks, and all of them blended together with various opacities of "grain merge." it's easy to learn to do shots like this, and available for everyone regardless of income. as you can see, this is done with the humblest of gear. that's why i like to call it, "Digital-Age Recession-Era Folk Art." so open the shutter of your mind ...! -=- Explore #5, April 8 2013. thanks SO much ... !!
See more photos in www.onlystreetphotography.com post a coment in my blog

After I had wrapped up my week in Torres Del Paine National Park, I drove back down to Puerto Natales, which is a wind blown town nestled against one of the many straights that make up with Patagonia. As I walked along the water, I came across these old pilings that must have supported a pier at some point in the past. It looked like a nice composition, with the storm clouds in the distance, so I set up my camera and used the Lee Big Stopper to smooth out the water.

Tianshan Park - Shanghai

I have been inspired to start experimenting with multiple exposure techniques after seeing the work of Rob Hudson, Valda Bailey and Chris Friel. All three are exploring interesting directions and I feel there is some real creative possibilities in this area. There is also a lot of technical issues created by the technique too and it is by no means easy to produce anything pleasing. I managed this image in the snow recently, shooting from a car (the old broken leg still preventing me from walking). I am itching to get mobile again so I can start trying out all the images I have in my head. I have been spending some time recently studying abstract art and this has been inspiring me in this direction too. I am hoping it might lead to some interesting images. You will find details on all of my photography workshops across the UK HERE See My Profile Page for links to my website, blog and free downloads. You can also sign up to my photography newsletter.

description._content: Ex Bluebird of Middleton now sporting its revised corporate livery.

I always seem to get these bleak and dreary looking shots when I shoot in the morning under overcast conditions.  I suppose it's because that's just how it really looks.  The strength of the waves was very unpredictable, so I was moving back and forth from the water line trying to set my tripod in a good position.  Of course I had the tripod legs spread wide for extra stability since the surf is pretty darn strong.  I retreated several times from various waves until finally I got caught by one that submerged my tripod up to the ball head and sprayed sea water all over my filters, lens, and camera body.  I think I grabbed my gear and ran just in the nick of time, but prematurely ended the photo shoot for the morning.

For this shot I initially tried a Lee 0.9 ND hard grad filter but found that the hard transition didn't work under the lighting conditions.  I switched to a 0.9 ND soft filter and that seemed to work better.

Red-capped Robin, Petroica goodenovii
+===============================+
Found this little dude, or better to say he found me, and was quite the noisy bird.  By the look of  his red cap feathers he's all moulted into his nice winter plumage.  He certainly was in no hurry, but I couldn't get him to turn front on to see all that wonderful chest.

Fido

A lucky trick of the camera angle and good jumping skills.

I started cycling pretty early in life, when I was around 5 years of age. The most cherished memories of my childhood are riding my little maroon and white bicycle in exquisite lush green tea-estates of Himalayas or exploring the colonial buildings of Dehradun. 
Now I ride a motor-cycle and don't have a bicycle anymore but often when I spot kids riding around, I do think of those good old days in the mountains...

Cuba, the time machine - XXVIII -

If you enter in a cuban house, you discover a totally different world.

For Me Again Monday's "Product Placement" theme, and a shout-out to Special K. The start to the week I'd like to have...and the reality of my kitchen table in the comments. Sorry to dispel the myth, but working from home isn't quite as laidback as most of my friends like to imagine. Heck...it's nowhere near what I'd like to imagine most days. (Although the commute to the kitchen table is pretty sweet) I've added some more notes of truth to the image, just to further burst the bubble of this commercial moment. HMAM (hope it included a balanced start wherever you are) And would you look at that! Today's ODC theme is FEAST!

photo.title: The Old Pharmacy in Visby, Gotland, Sweden

description._content: The Old Pharmacy at Strandgatan street in Visby. A medieval building with stepped gables. Pencil-drawing by Per Arvid Säve, from 1846. Gamla Apoteket vid Strandgatan i Visby. Ett medeltida trappgavelhus. Blyertseckning av Per Arvid Säve, från 1846. Collection: The P. A. Säve Collection, Archives of Swedish National Heritage Board Parish (socken): Visby Province (landskap): Gotland Municipality (kommun): Gotland County (län): Gotland Photograph by: Lars Kennerstedt Date: 2011 Persistent URL: kmb.raa.se/cocoon/bild/show-image.html?id=16001000327324 Read more about the photo database (in english): www.kms.raa.se/cocoon/bild/about.html

photo.title: Antares Test Flight Scheduled for April 17

description._content: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va.—Orbital Sciences Corp. completed roll-out of the first fully-integrated Antares rocket to the Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport Pad-0A at NASA's Wallops Flight Facility on Saturday, April 6. Orbital has confirmed an April 17 target launch date for the rocket test flight with a planned liftoff of 5 p.m. EDT. Orbital is testing the Antares rocket under NASA's Commercial Orbital Transportation Services (COTS) program. NASA initiatives like COTS are helping develop a robust U.S. commercial space transportation industry with the goal of achieving safe, reliable and cost-effective transportation to and from the space station and low-Earth orbit. For more information on the launch, Wallops, and NASA initiatives like COTS, see www.nasa.gov/centers/wallops/missions/antares.html Credit: NASA/Wallops/Brea Reeves NASA image use policy. NASA Goddard Space Flight Center enables NASA’s mission through four scientific endeavors: Earth Science, Heliophysics, Solar System Exploration, and Astrophysics. Goddard plays a leading role in NASA’s accomplishments by contributing compelling scientific knowledge to advance the Agency’s mission. Follow us on Twitter Like us on Facebook Find us on Instagram

Photo taken for the April 3012: A Month in Pictures Group. This is my Photo for 8th April. Bought some tulips last Friday and thought I'd better do something with them today. In the absence of any rain, I created a bit myself. Quite difficult setting the camera timer going, picking up and holding the reflector at the front and holding the watering can above the flowers. I've since tipped the tulips upside down to drain them off, and they are safely back in the kitchen windowsill. The rest of my set for the April 2013: A Month in Pictures Group can be found here: www.flickr.com/photos/janflicks/sets/72157633144156698/wi... and the link to the Group here: www.flickr.com/groups/aprilphotoadayforamonth/
